poem:
**The Storeroom at V&A East**

In a vast sea of objects, I choose  
a relic, lifting it into my small world—  
a ceramic teapot whispers histories  
from its glazed spout,  
or Bowie's guitar, still vibrant with echoes.  
Here, in a quiet room, time slips sideways,  
and I hold an unspoken link  
to the lingering mysteries of past lives.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Share your highlights from the V&A East Storehouse The V&A has launched a new exhibition space, the V&A East Storehouse in East London, where visitors can choose from over 250,000 objects and have one delivered to a room for a private viewing. A recent addition to the collection is the David Bowie Centre, containing the singer’s archive. We would like to hear from visitors to the V&A East Storehouse about their highlights. If you requested". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
